Preface.
The present new edition of Mr. Jäschke's Tibetan Grammar scarcely needs a word of apology. As the first edition which was lithographed at Kyela&ndota; in 1865 in a limited number of copies has long been out of print, Dr. Rost urged the author to revise his grammar for the purpose of bringing it out in an improved form. The latter, prevented by ill-health from undertaking the task, placed the matter in my hands, and had the goodness to make over to me his own manuscript notes and additions to the original work. Without his personal cooperation, however, I was unable to make any but a very sparing use of these, adding only a few remarks from Gyalrabs and Milaraspa, with some further remarks on the local vernacular of Western Tibet. Indeed, special attention has been paid throughout to this dialect; it is the one with which the author during his long residence at Kyela&ndota; had become most familiar, and with which the English in India are most likely to be brought into direct contact.
Besides the above mentioned additions, I have taken a number of examples from the Dza&ndota;lun, to make clearer some of the rules, and, with the same view, I have altered, here and there, the wording of the lithographed edition.
The order of the paragraphs has been retained throughout, and only one (23.) has been added for completeness' sake.
The system of transliteration is nearly the same as in the Dictionary, only for ny, ñ is used, and instead of &ebarb;, ä (respectively &amaumb;) has been thought to be a clearer representation of the sound intended. For the niceties of pronunciation the reader is referred to the Dictionary, as in this Grammar only the general rules have been given.
Finally I must express my warmest thanks to Dr. Rost, to whose exertions not only the printing of this Grammar is solely due, but who also rendered me much help in the correcting of the work.
Mayence, May 1883.
H. Wenzel.

div0.head: Part I.
Phonology.
div0.p:
1. The Alphabet. The Tibetan Alphabet was adapted from the Lañ&cgrasa;a (lAnya tsha) form of the Indian letters by &Tspas;on-mi-sam-bho-ta (thon mi sam b+ho ta) minister of king Sro&ndota;-tsan-gam-po (srong btsan sgam po ) about the year 632 (s. Köpp. II, 56). The Indian letters out of which the single Tibetan characters were formed are given in the following table in their Nāgari shape.
surd. aspir. sonant. nasal.
gutturals. ka ka ka kha kha &kspas;a ga ga ga nga "na &ndota;a
palatals. ca ca &cgrave;a cha cha &cgrasa;a ja ja &jgrave;a nya ~na ña
dentals. ta ta ta tha tha &tspas;a da da da na na na
labials. pa pa pa pha pha &pspas;a ba ba ba ma ma ma
palatal sibilants. tsa tsa tsha &tspas;sa dza dsa
semivowels wa va wa zha &zgrave;a za za 'a &lowarrow;a
ya ya ya ra ra ra la la la
sha "sa &sgrave;a sa sa sa ha ha ha a 'a
It is seen from this table that several signs have been added to express sounds that are unknown in Sanscrit. The sibilants tsa _tsha _dza evidently were differentiated from the palatals. But as in transcribing Sanscrit words the Tibetans substitute their sibilants for the palatals of the original (as tsi na for ciina), we must suppose that the sibilisation of those consonants, common at present among the Hindus on the Southern slopes of the Himālaya (who say tsār for caar, four etc.), was in general use with those Indians from whom the Tib. Alphabet was taken (cf. also the Afghan څ and ڂ likewise sprung from ch and j). wa is differentiated from ba , which itself often is pronounced v, as shewn in the sequel; in transcribing Sanscrit, ba and va both are given, generally, by ba only. zha seems to be formed out of sha to which it is related in sound. za evidently is only the inverted ja . a corresponds with Sanscrit a. 'a is newly invented; for its functions see the following §§.—The letters which are peculiar to Sanscrit are expressed, in transcribing, in the following manner. a) The linguals, simply by inverting the signs of the dentals: thus, Ta .ta, Tha .tha, Da .da, Na .na. b) The sonant aspirates, by putting ha under the sonants: thus, g+ha gha, dz+ha jha, T+ha .dha, d+ha dha, b+ha bha.A very clear exposition of the ramification of Indian alphabets by Dr. Haas is to be found in the Publications of the Palaeographical Society Oriental Series IV, pl. XLIV.
2. Remarks.
1. Regarding the pronunciation of the single letters, as given above, it is to be born in mind, that surds ka _ta _pa are uttered without the least admixture of an aspiration, viz. as k, t, p are pronounced in the words skate, stale, spear; the aspirates kha _tha _pha forcibly, rather harder than the same in Kate, tale, peer; the sonants ga _da _ba like g, d, b in gate, dale, beer.
2. The same difference of hardness is to be observed in ca _cha _ja or &cgrave;, &cgrasa;, &jgrave; (&cgrasa; occurs in church; &cgrave;, the same without aspiration; &jgrave; in judge) and in tsa _tsha _dza or ts, &tspas;s, ds.
3. zha is the soft modification of &sgrave; or the s in leisure (French j in jamais, but more palatal).
4. nga is the English ng in sing, but occurs in Tibetan often at the commencement of a syllable.
5. nya ñ is the Hindi nya, or the initial sound in the word new, which would be spelled nyu ñu.
6. In the dialects of Eastern or Chinese-Tibet, however, the soft consonants ga _da _ba _ja _dza , when occurring as initials, are pronounced with an aspiration, similar to the Hindi gha, dha, bha, jha, or indeed so that they often scarcely differ from the common English k, t, p, ch; also zha and za are more difficult to distinguish from sha and sa than in the Western provinces (Exceptions s. §§ 7. 8).
3. Vowels.
1. Since every consonant sign implies, like its Sanscrit prototype, a following a, unless some other vowel sign is attached to it, no particular sign is wanted to denote this vowel, except in some cases specified in the
following §§. The special vowel signs are ེ, ི, ོ, ུ, pronounced respectively as e, i, o, u are in German, Italian and most other European languages, viz. ེ like ay in say, or e in ten; ི like i in machine, tin; ོ like o in so, on; ུ like u in rule, pull. It ought to be specially remarked that all vowels, including e and o (unlike the Sanscrit vowels from which they have taken their signs) are short, since no long vowels at all occur in the Tibetan language, except under particular circumstances, mentioned below (s. § 9. 5, 6).
2. When vowels are initial, a is used as their base, as is A in Urdu, e.g. a ma ama, ‘mother’.
3. 'a is originally different from a , as the latter denotes the opening of the previously closed throat for pronouncing a vowel with that slight explosive sound which the Arabs mean by 'a (hmrn"hhmz"h), as the a in the words: the lily, an endogen, which would be in Tibetan characters li li an ; 'a on the contrary is the mere vowel without that audible opening of the throat (as Arabic A without ||), as in Lilian, li li 'an . In Eastern Tibet this difference is strictly observed; and if the vowel is o or u the intentional exertion for avoiding the sound of a makes it resemble wo and wu: 'o ma ‘the milk’, almost like wo-ma, 'ug pa ‘the owl’ = wug-pa. In western Tibet this has been obliterated, and 'a is there spoken just like a .
4. Syllables. The Tibetan language is monosyllabic, that is to say all its words consist of one syllable only, which indeed may be variously composed, though the
component parts cannot, in every case, be recognised in their individuality. The mark for the end of such a syllable is a dot, called tsheg &tspas;seg, put at the right side of the upper part of the closing letter, such as ka the syllable ka. This &tspas;seg must invariably be put at the end of each written syllable, except before a &sgrave;ad (§ 10), in which case only nga &ndota;a retains its &tspas;seg. If therefore such a dot is found after two or more consonants, this will indicate that all of them, some way or other, form one syllable with only one vowel in it: ka ra ka-ra, kar kar (cf. §§ 5. 8).
5. Final consonants.
1. Only the following ten: ga _nga _ta _na _ba _ma _'a _ra _la _sa (and the four with affixed sa, v. 5) occur at the end of a syllable.
2. It must be observed, that ga _da _ba as finals are never pronounced like the English g, d, b in leg, bad, cab, but are transformed differently in the different provinces. In Ladak they sound like k, t, p e.g. sog = sock, god = got, thob = top.
3. In all Central Tibet, moreover, final da and na , sometimes even la , modify the sound of a preceding vowel: a to ä (similar to the English a in hare, man), o into öb; (French eu in jeu), u into üb; (French u in mur). In most of the other provinces ga and da are uttered so indistinctly as to be scarcely audible, so that sog , god become s&obreve;&mlapos;, g&obreve;&mlapos;. In Tsang even final la is scarcely perceptible, and final ga , particularly after o, is almost dissolved into a vowel sound = a: sol ba so-wa,
dkon mchog kon-choa.This is the form in which the word, chosen by the missionaries to express the Christian “God” (cf. dict.), has found its way into several popular works.
4. Final sa is sounded as s only in Northern Ladak; elsewhere it changes into i or disappears entirely, prolonging, or even modifying at the same time the preceding vowel. Thus the following words: nas ‘barley’, shes ‘know’, ris ‘figure’, chos ‘religion’, lus ‘body’, are pronounced in Northern Ladak: năs, &sgrave;&ebreve;s, ris, &cgrasa;os, lŭs; in Lahoul: nai, shei, rī, &cgrasa;ō, lū; in Lhasa, and consequently by everyone who wishes to speak elegantly: n&amaumb;, &sgrave;ē, rī, &cgrasa;&omaumb;, l&umaumb;.
5. In some words final sa occurs as a second closing letter (affix), after ga _nga _ba _ma , as in nags ‘forest’, gangs ‘glacier-ice’, thabs ‘means’, rams ‘indigo’; these are pronounced in N. Ladak: nacks, ga&ndota;s, &tspas;aps, rams, elsewhere nack (in Ü: nā), ga&ndota; (ET ghang), &tspas;ap, ram.
6. na before pa and ma is especially in ET very often pronounced m, e.g. nyan pa ñäm-pa, nyon pa ñöm-pa, snyem pa snyen pa ñem-pa.
6. Diphthongs.
1. They occur in Tibetan writing only where one of the vowels i, o, u have to be added to a word ending with an other vowel (s. §§ 15. 1; 33. 1; 45. 2). These additional vowels are then always written 'i , 'o , 'u , never i etc. (cf. § 3. 3); and the combinations ai, oi, ui (as in bka'i , mgo'i , bu'i ) are pronounced very much like &amaumb;, &omaumb;, &umaumb;, so that the syllables na'i , she'i , ri'i , cho'i ,
lu'i can only in some vulgar dialects be distinguished from those mentioned in § 5. 4. 2. The others ao, eo, io, oo, uo, au, eu, iu (bka'o , skye'o , bgyi'o , 'gro'o , 'du'o , ga'u , bye'u , khyi'u ) are pronounced in rapid succession, but each vowel is distinctly audible. In prosody they are generally regarded as one syllable, but if the verse should require it they may be counted as two.
7. Compound consonants.
1. They are expressed in writing by putting one below the other, in which case several change their original figure.
Subscribed consonants.
2. The letter y subjoined to another is represented by the figure ྱ, and occurs in connection with the three gutturals and labials, and with m, thus kya _khya _gya _pya _phya _bya _mya . The former three have preserved, in most cases, their original pronunciation kya, &kspas;ya, gya (the latter in ET: ghya s. § 2. 6). In the Mongol pronunciation of Tibetan words, however, they have been corrupted into &cgrave;, &cgrasa;, &jgrave; respectively, a well known instance of which is the common pronunciation Kan&jgrave;ur i.o. kangyur, or eleg. ka-gyur (bka' 'gyur ). pya , phya , byabya are almost everywhere spoken without any difference from ca, cha, ja (except in the Western dialect before e and i, where the y is dropped and pa, pha, ba alone are pronounced). mya is spoken ny = nya.
3. r occurs at the foot of the gutturals, dentals, labials, of na, ma, sa, and ha, in the shape of ྲ. In some parts of the country, as in Purig, these combinations
are pronounced literally, like kra, khra etc., but by far the most general custom is to sound them like the Indian cerebrals, viz. kra, tra, pra indiscriminately = .ta &tdotb;; khra, thra, phra = .tha &tdotb;h; gra, dra, bra = .da &ddotb; (in CT: &ddotb;h); only in the case of bra the literal pronunciation br is not uncommon. In n+ra and mra both letters are distinctly heard; hra sounds like shr in shrub, and so does sra generally. In Ü this r is dropped nearly in all cases: thus, phra &pspas;a, sra sa etc.
4. Six letters are often found with an la beneath: kla _gla _bla _zla _rla _sla ; in these the la alone is pronounced, except in zla , which sounds da.
5. The figure ྭ, sometimes found at the foot of a letter is used in Sanscrit words to express the subscribed va, as in s+wA hA (cf. § 9. 6) for svaahaa; and is now pronounced by Tibetans = ō: sōhā; in words originally Tibetan it now exists merely as an orthographical mark, to distinguish homonyms in writing, as tsha &tspas;sa, ‘hot’ and tshwa &tspas;sa, ‘salt’; but, as it is spoken, in some words at least, in Balti (e.g. rtswa rtswa ‘grass’), it must be supposed that, in the primitive form of the language, it was generally heard.—Note. Of such compounds, indeed, as phywa ‘lot’ it is difficult to understand, how they can have been pronounced literally, if the v was not, perhaps, pronounced before the y.
Superadded consonants.
6. r over another consonant is written ⸆, and 11 consonants have this sign: rka _rga _rnga _rta _rda _rna _rba _rma _rtsa _rdza , above nya it preserves
its full shape, as better adapted to the form of that letter: thus, rnya . In speaking it is seldom heard except provincially, and in some instances in compound words after a vowel thus, u rgyan Urgyán, Urgyén, ancient name of the country of Lahore; rdo rje dórje ‘va&jgrave;ra’. Ladakees often pronounce it = s: rta sta ‘horse’ elsewhere ta.
7. Similar is the usage in those with a superadded la (namely: the surds and sonants of the first four classes, the guttural nasal, and ha), which latter is often softly heard in WT, but entirely dropped elsewhere, except in the case of lha, which is spoken = la in WT, but with a distinct aspiration = hla or lha in ET.
8. sa is superadded to the gutturals, dentals and labials with exception of the aspiratae, then nya and tsa . It is, in many cases, distinctly pronounced in Ladak, but dropped elsewhereThis will be indicated in the following examples by including the s in parentheses, as (s)kom..
9. ga _da _ba _ja _dza with any superadded letter lose the aspiration mentioned in § 2. 6 and sound = g, d, b, &jgrave;, ds.
10. rja _rtsa _rdza often lose even the inherent t-sound in pronunciation and are spoken like &jgrave;, s, z.

8. Prefixed letters.
1. The five letters ga _da _ba _ma _'a frequently occur before the real, radical initials of other words, but are seldom pronounced, except in similar cases as § 7. 6. ga occurs before ca _nya _ta _da _na _tsa _zha _za _ya _sha _sa ; da before the gutturals and labials with exception of the aspiratae; ba before ka _ga , the palatals, dentals and palatal sibilants with the same exception as under da, then zha _za _ra _sha _sa ; ma before the gutturals, palatals, dentals and palatal sibilants, except the surds; 'a before the aspiratae and sonants of the five classes. In CT, to pronounce them in any case, is considered vulgar.
2. The ambiguity which would arise in case of the prefix standing before one of the 10 final consonants, as single radical, the vowel being the unwritten a,—e.g. in the syllable dag , which, if da is radical, has to be pronounced dag, if prefixed gā,—is avoided by adding an 'a in the latter case: thus, dga' . Other examples are: gad gad (&gspas;ä&mlapos;) and gda' dā; bas bas (b&amaumb;, &bspas;&amaumb;) and bsa' sā; mad mad (mä&mlapos;) and mda' dā; 'ga' gā. This 'a is added, though the radical be not one of the mentioned letters; as, bka' kā.
3. da as a prefix and ba as first radical annul each other, so that only the following sound is heard, as will be seen in the
following examples (dbang etc.).
4. Another irregularity is the nasal pronunciation of the prefixed 'a in compounds after a vowel, which is often heard e.g. dge 'dun pronounced gen-dún, gen-d&uacuumlb;n, but eleg.: ge-d&uacuumlb;n, ‘clergy’; bka' 'bum kam-bum, eleg. ka-búm, ‘the 100 000 precepts’ (title of a book).—Note. With regard to the aspiration of the soft consonants in ET the prefixed letters have the same influence as the superadded ones § 7. 9.

9. Word; Accent; Quantity.
1. The peculiarity of the Tibetan mode of writing in distinctly marking the word-syllables, but not the words (cf. § 4) composed of two or more of these, sometimes renders it doubtful what is to be regarded as one word.
2. There exist a great number of
small monosyllables, which serve to denote different shades of notions, grammatical relations etc., and are postponed to the word in question; but never alter its original shape, though their own initials are not seldom influenced by its final consonant (cf. § 15).
3. Such monosyllables may conveniently be regarded as terminations, forming one word together with the preceding nominal or verbal root.
4. The accent is, in such cases, most naturally given to the root, or, in compounds, generally to the latter part of the composition, as: mig mig, ‘eye’, mig gi míg-gi, ‘of the eye’; lag lag, ‘hand’, lag_shubs lag shubs lag-&sgrave;ub(s), ‘hand-covering, glove’.—
5. Equally natural is, in WT, the quantity of the vowels: accentuated vowels, when closing the syllable, are comparatively long (though never so long as in the English words bee, stay, or Hindi rAjA etc.), otherwise short, as mi mī ‘man’, mi la mī-lă ‘to the man’, but mar măr, ‘butter’.—In CT, however, even accentuated and closing vowels are uttered very shortly: m&ibreve;, m&ibreve;-lă etc., and long ones occur there only in the case of § 5, 4. 5. and 8, 2., as las l&amaumb; ‘work’; chos &cgrasa;&omaumb; ‘religion’; mda' dā ‘arrow’; gza' zā ‘planet’; and in Lhasa especially: nags nā ‘forest’; legs pa lē-pa ‘good’; rigs rī ‘class, sort’; logs lō ‘side’; lugs lū ‘manner’.—In Sanscrit words the long vowels are marked by an 'a beneath the consonant, as: nA ma (naama) ‘called’, mU la (muula) ‘root’ (s. § 3).
10. Punctuation. For separating the members of a longer period, a vertical stroke: /, called shad &sgrave;ad (&sgrave;ä&mlapos;), is used, which corresponds at once to our comma, semicolon and colon; after the closing of a sentence the same is doubled; after a longer piece, e.g. a chapter, four &sgrave;ads are put. No marks of interrogation or exclamation exist in punctuation.—
2. In metrical compositions, the double &sgrave;ad is used for separating the single verses; in that case the logical partition of the sentence is not marked (cf. § 4).

Part II.
Etymology.
Chapter I.
The Article.
11. Peculiarities of the Tibetan article.
1. What have been called Articles by Csoma and Schmidt, are a number of little affixes: pa _ba _ma _po _bo _mo , and some similar ones, which might perhaps be more adequately termed denominators, since their principal object is undoubtedly to represent a given root as a noun, substantive or adjective, as is most clearly perceptible in the instance of the roots of verbs, to which pa or ba impart the notion of the Infinitive and Participle, or the nearest abstract and nearest concrete nouns that can possibly be formed from the idea of a verb. These affixes are not, however,—except in this case—essential to a noun, as many substantives and adjectives and most of the pronouns are never accompanied by them, and even those which usually appear connected with them, will drop them upon the slightest occasion.
2. Almost the only case in which a syntactical use of them, like that of the English definite Article, is perceptible, is that mentioned § 20. 3; a formal one, that of distinguishing the Gender, occurs in a limited number of words, where mo denotes the female, po the masculine. Thus: rgyal po gyál-po ‘king’, rgyal mo gyál-mo ‘queen’. Or,
if the word in the masculine (or rather common) gender has no article, mo is added: seng ge sé&ndota;-ge ‘lion’, seng ge moseng ge mo ‘lioness’.
3. In most instances, by far, their only use is to distinguish different meanings of homonymous roots, e.g. ston pa (s)tón-pa (t&oacuumlb;n-pa), ‘teacher’; ston mo (s)tón-mo (t&oacuumlb;n-mo) ‘feast’; ston kha (s)tón-&kspas;a (t&oacuumlb;n-&kspas;a) ‘autumn’. Even this advantage, however, is given up, as soon as a composition takes place, and then the meaning can only be inferred from the context, or known from usage: ming ston (from ston mo ) ‘name feast’ (given on the occasion of naming or christening an infant); ston zla (from ston kha ) ‘autumnal month’. In some instances the putting or omitting of these articles is optional; more frequently the usage varies in different provinces.
4. The peculiar nature of these affixes is most clearly shown by the manner in which they are connected with the indefinite article § 13.
Note. The affixes ba _bo are after vowels and after the consonants nga _ra _la always pronounced wa and wo, instead of ba and bo; thus, dka' ba ka-wa ‘difficult’; re ba re-wa ‘hope’; gang ba ga&ndota;-wa (gh°) ‘full’; zer ba zer-wa (ser-wa) ‘to say’; myal ba nyal-wa ‘hell’; jo bo jo-wo (jho-wo) ‘lord, master’.
12. Difference of the Articles among each other.
1. The usage of pa _ba _ma is the most general and widest of all,
as they occur with all sorts of substantives and other nouns. pa is particularly used for denoting a man who is in a certain way connected with a certain thing (something like UAlA and dAr in Hindustāni and Persian): grwa &ddotb;a ‘school’, grwa pa (literally: scholar) ‘disciple, novice’; chu &cgrasa;u ‘water’, chu pa ‘water-carrier’ (pAnI UAlA); rta ‘horse’, rta pa ‘horseman’; dbus ‘the province of &Umaumb;’, dbus pa ‘a man from &Umaumb;’, khye'u &kspas;yëu ‘boy’, lo lo ‘year’, gnyis ñi(s) ‘two’, hence: khye'u lo gnyis pa ‘a two years' boy’. If the feminine is required ma is either added to, or—more commonly—used instead of, the former: dbus ma ‘a woman from &Umaumb;’; bu mo lo gnyis ma ‘a two years' girl’. The performer of an action is more frequently denoted by po (or, in more solemn language, pa po ), though, in conversation at least, mkhan &kspas;an (&kspas;&ebarb;n), is preferred; byed pa &jgrave;ed-pa ‘to do, make; doing, making’: byed po , byed pa po , byed mkhan ‘the doer, maker’.
2. The appendices ka _kha _ga occur with a limited number of nouns only, especially the names of the seasons, with numerals, and some pronouns. (ko seems to be a vulgar form of pronunciation for ka ).
13. The indefinite Article. This is the numeral one (§ 13), only deprived of its prefix, viz.: cig , which form it retains, if the preceding word ends with ga _da _ba , as: khab cig
&kspas;ab-&cgrave;ig, a needle; it is changed to shig after sa , ras shig ras-&sgrave;ig, rä-&sgrave;ig, a cloth; to zhig &zgrave;ig (&sgrave;ig) in all other cases. Some authors use cig after any termination indiscriminately. It is, of course, always without accent. The articles pa _ba etc. are not superseded by the indefinite article e.g. ston pa ‘teacher, the teacher’, ston pa zhig ‘a teacher’. It is used even after a plurality: thus, chu mig bzhi zhig de ru yod ‘there were some four wells’, and even: mang zhig gda' ste ‘there being a multitude of them’ (from Mil.). Very often it is placed after the interrogative pronouns (v. 27), and sometimes its original meaning is obscured so much that it occurs even after known and definite subjects, where one would expect the demonstrative (see f.i. Dzl. 25, 1. 28, 6. 128, 14).
Chapter II.
The Substantive.
14. The Number. The Plural is denoted by adding the word rnams nam, or, more rarely, dag dag (&dspas;ag), tsho , or a few other words, which originally were nouns with the common notion of plurality. But this mark of the Plural is usually omitted, when the plurality of the thing in question may be known from other circumstances, e.g. when a numeral is added: thus, mi ‘man’, mi rnams ‘men’, mi gsum ‘three men’. When a substantive is connected with an adjective, the plural sign is added only once, viz. after the
last of the connected words: mi bzang po rnams ‘the good men’.
Note. The conversational language uses the words rnams etc. seldom, in WT scarcely ever (an exception s. 24. Remarks), but adds, when necessary, such words as: all, many, some; two, three, seven, eight, or other suitable numerals (cf. § 20, 5.).
15. Declension. The regular addition of the different particles or single sounds by which the cases are formed is the same for all nouns, whether substantives or adjectives, pronouns or participles. Only in some cases, in the Dative and Instrumental, the noun itself is changed, when, ending in a vowel, it admits of a closer connection with the corrupted case-sign. We may reckon in Tibetan seven cases, expressive of all the relations, for which cases are used in other languages, viz: nominative and accusative, genitive, instrumental, dative, locative, ablative, terminative and vocative.
1. The unaltered form of the noun has some of the functions of our Nominative and those of the Accusative and Vocative.
2. The sign of the Genitive is kyi after words with the finals da _ba _sa ; gyi after na _ma _ra _la , gi after ga and nga ; after vowels i is simply added by means of an 'a thus: 'i , which then will form a diphthong with the vowel of the noun (cf. § 6), or if, in versification, two syllables are required, i appears supported by an ya forming a distinct word.
3. The Instrumental or Agent is expressed by the particles kyis , gyis or gis after the respective
consonants as specified above; after vowels simply sa is added, or, in verse, sometimes yis .
Note. The instrumental is, in modern pronunciation, except in Northern Ladak, scarcely discernible from the genitive, and there are but few if any, even among lamas, who are not liable to confound both cases in writing.
In the language of common life, in WT, the different forms of the particle of the genitive and instrumental, after consonants, kyi _gyi etc. are never heard, but everywhere the final consonant is doubled and the vowel i added to it, thus: lus , G. lus-si (Ld.), l&umaumb;-i; lam , G. lam-mi; gser (gold), G. ser-ri etc; or, in other words, all nouns ending in consonants are formed like those ending with ga (see the example mig ). In those ending with a vowel no irregularity takes place.
4. The Dative adds indiscriminately the postposition la la, denoting the relation of space in the widest sense, expressed by the English prepositions in, into, at, on, to.
5. The Locative is formed by the postposition na na ‘in’.
6. The Ablative by nas n&amaumb; or las l&amaumb; ‘from’ (the latter especially with the meaning: from among), all three likewise without any discriminating regard to the ending of the noun.
7. The Terminative is expressed by the postpositions ru or ra after vowels; tu after final ga and ba and, in certain words, da _ra _la ; su after sa ; du generally after na _ra _la and the other final consonants. All these
postpositions denote the motion to or into.
8. The Vocative is not different from the Nominative (as stated above), if not distinguished by the interjection kye oh!, and can only be known from the context.

Chapter III.
The Adjective.
16. In the Tibetan language the Adjective is not formally distinguished from the Substantive, so that many nouns may be used one or the other way just as circumstances require.But the vulgar language has a predilection for certain forms of Adjectives
1. those with the gerundial particle te , as: tshan te for the more classical tshan ‘warm’; these seem to be particularly in use in Tsa&ndota;: mdza' ste ‘friendly’, less so in Ü.
2. compound adjectives either by simple reiteration of the root: ril ril for ril po ‘round’, or changing the vowel at the same time: khrag khrug ‘complicate’, gtsang gtsong ‘awry’ etc. Often they are quadrisyllables after this form: mal la mul le ‘lukewarm’, chag ga chog ge ‘medley’. The declension, likewise, follows the same rules as that of substantives. Only two remarks may be added here.
1. The particles pa _ma _po _mo are not very strictly used for distinguishing the gender, since even in the case of human beings pa and po are not seldom found connected with feminines, e.g.: bu mo mdzes pa just as well as bu mo mdzes ma ‘a fine girl’.
2. The Adjective stands after the Substantive to which it belongs: thus, ri mthon po ri-&tspas;ón-po, C: ri-&tspas;öb;n-po, ‘the high hill’, when, of course, the case-signs
are joined to the Adjective: ri mthon po'i ‘of the high hill’, ri mthon po rnams ‘the high hills’ etc.
Or the Adjective may be put in the Gen. before the Substantive: mthon po'i ri , and then the latter only is declined: mthon po'i ri'i , mthon po'i ri rnams . In the vulgar speech both of C and WT the adjective sometimes preserves, even in this position, its simple form (Nominative). A third way of expression, when both are joined together, without any article, as skam sa instead of sa skam po ‘the dry land’, is rather a compound substantive, with the same difference of meaning as ‘highland’ and ‘a high land’ in English.
17. Comparison.
1. Special terminations, expressive of the different degrees of comparison, as in the Aryan languages, do not exist in Tibetan. There are two particles, however, corresponding to the English than: bas , after the final consonants nga _ra _la and after vowels (pas , after ga _da _na _ba _ma _sa Some Mscr. and wood-prints, however, prefer, even after these consonants, the form bas .), and las ; these particles follow the word with which another is compared (like the Hind. sE) and this then precedes the compared one, finally follows the adjective in the positive: rta bas (or las ) khyi chung ba yin ‘horse—than dog small is’, just as in Hindūstāni: g-hU'rI sIsE kttA chhU'tA haI. But also the position usual in
our European languages occurs, thus: rab tu 'byung ba'i bsod nams ri rab lhun po bas 'phangs mtho'o ‘the merit of becoming a priest is relatively higher than mount Meru’; bod gyi rgyal po gzhan las che ba yin no ‘the king of Tibet is greater than the other ones’. The particle bas (pas ) may be put, in the same manner, after adverbs. Thus, sngar bas gsal bar mthong bar gyur to ‘(their eyes) became more keen-sighted than before’. Or, after infinitives, gzhan song ba bas nu bos song na phan ‘it is better (for him) that his younger brother should go (with him) than another’. las for itself has the meaning of ‘more than’, with the negative: ‘not more than’, ‘only’; thus: nga la srang gnyis las ni mi dgos ‘more than two ounces I do not want’ (cf. vulg. WT: gsum man na med ‘there are not more than (only) three’); or ‘nothing but’, ‘only’, ri dwags shor ba las dga' ba med ‘there is no pleasure (for us) but hunting, h. is our only pl.’.
2. An Adverb which augments the notion of the adjective itself, is lhag par ‘more’; this can be added ad libitum: rta bas khyi lhag par chung ba yin .
3. Another adverb, je means: ‘more and more’, ‘gradually more’, e.g. je nye je nye song ste ‘going nearer and nearer’.
4. ‘The elder—the younger’ e.g. of two brothers, is
simply expressed by: ‘the great—the little’.
5. The Superlative is paraphrased by the same means: kun las chen po or thams cad pas chen po ‘greater than all’. Or it is expressed in the following manner: yul gyi rgyal po'i nang na rgyal po gang che ‘of (among) the kings of the country which one is the greatest (prop. great)?’. Adverbs for expressing high degrees are: shin tu or rab tu ‘very’, kun tu ‘all’, yongs su ‘quite’, mchog tu ‘exceedingly’ etc.
Note. The colloquial language of WT uses sang instead of bas or las , and mA (mā, always with a strong emphasis, perhaps a mutilated form of mangs ‘much’) or mang po instead of shin tu , whereas that of CT employs las in the former case, but repeats the adjective in the latter, so that ‘very large’ is expressed in books by shin tu chen po , in speaking, in WT by m&amacracu; &cgrasa;én-po, in CT by &cgrasa;em-po &cgrasa;em-po.

19. Ordinals. dang po W: da&ndota;-po, C: &dspas;° ‘the first’, the rest are simply formed by adding pa to the cardinals, as: gnyis pa , ‘the second’ etc.; the 21st is nyi shu rtsa gcig pa ‘the twenty-oneth’, not, as in English, ‘the twenty first’.
20. Remarks.
1. The smaller number postponed indicates, as is seen in § 18, addition, the reverse—multiplication: bcu gsum 13, sum cu 30; but in the latter case the three first numerals are changed to chig , nyi , sum ; and bcu , as the second part of a compound after consonants, is spelled cu .
2. The words tham pa (after full tens up to one hundred), phrag (after hundreds and thousandsphrag is used especially if the number counting the hundreds,
thousands etc. follows: thus, stong phrag nyi shustong phrag nyi shu ‘of thousands: twenty, 20 000’; khri phrag du ma ‘many ten-thousands’.),
tsho (with still greater numbers), are optional but frequent additions. rtsa is common instead of dang ‘and’, to connect units with tens (s. § 18), but it occurs also with hundreds and thousands, and not seldom together with dang , e.g. stong dang rtsa gnyis , 1002. It is used also instead of tham pa , as: bcu rtsa ten, nyi shu rtsa twenty; often it is standing alone for nyi shu rtsa , as rtsa gnyis , twenty two. This latter custom may have caused the belief, common even among educated readers in C and WT, that rtsa must mean twenty, even when connecting a hundred or thousand to a unit, as they will usually understand the above mentioned number in the sense of 1022 instead of 1002; but the authority of printed books, wherever the exact number can be verified from other circumstances, does not confirm this, which would indeed be a sadly ambiguous phraseology.
3. ka added to a cardinal number means conjunction: gnyis ka , the two together, both; gsum ka , the three together, all three etc. po means either the same, or represents the definite article, indicating that the number has been already mentioned, e.g. mi lnga****_btang ngo*/___/mi lnga po bsleb ste****, five men were sent.... The five men arriving etc.
4. pa is used, besides
forming Ordinals, to express the notion of ‘containing’, e.g. yi ge drug pa ‘that containing six letters’, viz. the famous formula: oM ma Ni pa d+me hUM om ma&ndotb;i padme hum; sum cu pa ‘that containing thirty (letters)’, the Tibetan alphabet.
5. Such combinations as gnyis gsum etc. are frequently used in common life, to denote a number approximately, ‘two or three or so’ (cf. § 14 Note).
21. Distributive numerals. They are expressed by repetition as in Hind.: drug drug each time six, six for each etc. In composed numerals only the last member is repeated, thus sum cu rtsa gnyis gnyis each time thirty two.
22. Adverbial numerals.
1. Firstly, secondly etc. are formed from the ordinals as every Adverb is from an Adjective, viz. by adding the letter ra , dang por , gnyis par etc. (s. § 41).
2. Multiplicative adverbs, ‘once’, ‘twice’ etc., are expressed by putting lan ‘times’ before the cardinal: lan gcig , lan gnyis , W: lan-&cgrave;ig, lan-ñi(s), C: län-&cgrave;ig, län-ñī ‘once, twice’ etc.: seldom tsher , tshar , thengs with the same meaning as lan .
23. Fractional numerals are formed by adding cha ‘part’: thus, brgya'i cha ‘a hundredth part’ etc., but also: bang mdzod gsum cha zhig ‘one third of the treasury’.
Chapter V.
Pronouns.
24. Personal Pronouns. First person: nga &ndota;a; nged &ndota;ed, &ndota;&ebreve;&mlapos;; ngos &ndota;os (Ld.); kho bo &kspas;o-wo, masc., and kho mo &kspas;o-mo, fem.; bdag dag ‘self’—‘I’; Second person: khyod &kspas;yod (&kspas;yö&mlapos;), khyed &kspas;yed (&kspas;y&ebreve;&mlapos;) ‘thou, you’; Third person: kho &kspas;o, khong &kspas;o&ndota;—‘he, she, it’.
The plural is formed by adding cag , rnams , cag rnams or tsho , but very often, if circumstances show the meaning with sufficient certainty, the sign of the plural is altogether omitted. The declension is the same as that of the substantives.
Remarks: nga is the most common and can be used by every body; nged seems to be preferred in elegant speech (s. Note); ngos is very common in modern letter-writing, at least in WT; bdag ‘self’, when speaking to superior persons occurs very often in books, but has disappeared from common speech, except in the province of Tsa&ndota; (&Tdotb;a&sgrave;ilhunpo) as also the following; kho bo , kho mo in easy conversation with persons of equal rank, or to inferiors.
2. person. khyod is used in books in addressing even the highest persons, but in modern conversation only among equals or to inferiors; khyed is elegant and respectful, especially in books.—
3. person. kho seldom occurs in books, where the demonstr. pron. de (§ 26) is generally used instead; khong is common to both the written and the spoken language, and used, at least in the latter, as respectful. But it must be remarked that the pronoun of the third person is in most cases entirely omitted, even when there is a change of subject.—Instead of nga cag and khyod cag the people of WT use nga zha and khyo zha ; the vulgar plural of kho is kho pa .—
To each of these pronouns may be added: rang ra&ndota; or nyid ñid, ñ&ibreve;&mlapos; ‘self’, and in conversational language nga rang , khyod rang , kho rang are, perhaps, even more frequently used than the simple forms, without any difference in the meaning. nyid is more prevalent in books, except the compound nyid rang ñi-ra&ndota;, which is in modern speech the usual respectful pronoun of address, like ‘Sie’ in German.
Note. The predilection of Eastern Asiatics for a system of ceremonials in the language is met with also in Tibetan. There is one separate class of words, which must be used in reference to the honoured person, when spoken to as well as when spoken of. To this class belong, besides the pronouns nyid rang , khyed , khong , all the respectful terms by which the body or soul, or parts of the same, and all things or persons pertaining to such a person, and
even his actions, must be called. The terms, most frequently occurring, have special expressions, as sku (s)ku, instead of lus lus, l&umaumb;, ‘body’; dbu u, i.o. mgo go ‘head’; thugs &tspas;ug(s) (Ü: &tspas;ū), i.o. sems sem(s) ‘soul’, or yid yid, y&ibreve;&mlapos;, ‘mind’; yab yab, i.o. pha (vulg: a pha ), ‘father’; na bza' na-za, i.o. gos gos, g&omaumb;, ‘coat’, ‘dress’; chibs &cgrasa;ib(s), i.o. rta (r)ta, sta ‘horse’; bzhugs pa &zgrave;ug(s)-pa (Ü: &zgrave;ū-pa), i.o. sdod pa dod-pa, dö&mlapos;-pa ‘to sit’; mdzad pa dzad-pa, dzä&mlapos;-pa i.o. byed pa &jgrave;ed-pa, &jgrave;h&ebreve;&mlapos;-pa ‘to make’ and many others. If there is no such special word, any substantive may be rendered respectful by adding sku or thugs respectively (so, sku tshe i.o. tshe ‘lifetime’; thugs khro ba i.o. khro ba ‘anger’) and any verb by adding mdzan pa , according to 39, 1. Another class of what might be called elegant terms are to be used when conversing with an honoured person (or also by a high person speaking of himself), such as bgyid pa gyid-pa, gy&ibreve;&mlapos;-pa ‘to do’; mchis pa &cgrasa;ī-pa ‘to be’; slad du lad-du, lä&mlapos;-du i.o. phyir du ‘for the sake of’, without reference to the said person himself. Even uneducated people know, and make use of, most of the ‘respectful’ terms, but the merely ‘elegant’ ones are, at least in WT, seldom or never heard in conversation.
25. Possessive pronouns. The Possessive is simply
expressed by the Genitive of the Personal, nga'i , khyod kyi etc. ‘His’, ‘her’, ‘its’, when referring to the acting subject (suus), must be expressed by rang gi or nyid kyi ‘his own’; otherwise (ejus) by kho'i , khong gi , de'i . In C, in the latter case, nga can , khyod can , kho can are used.
26. Reflective and Reciprocal pronouns.
1. The Reflective pronoun, ‘myself’, ‘yourself’ etc. is expressed by rang , nyid , also bdag . But in the case of the same person being the subject and object of an action, it must be paraphrased, so for ‘he precipitated himself from the rock’ must be said ‘he precipitated his own body etc.’ rang gi lus ; for ‘he rebuked himself’—‘he rebuked his own soul’ rang gi sems .—2. The reciprocal pronoun ‘each other’ or ‘one another’ is rendered by ‘one—one’, as gcig gis gcig bsad ‘by one one was killed’, ‘they killed one another’; gcig la gcig na re ‘to one one said’, ‘they said to each other’.
27. Demonstrative pronouns.
1. 'di di, ‘this’; de de, dhe ‘that’ are those most frequently used, both in books and speaking. The Plural is generally formed by dag , but also by rnams and tsho . More emphatical are 'di ka , 'di ga , 'di ko , 'di go , ‘just this’, ‘this same’; de ka etc. ‘that same’.—The vulgar dialect also uses ha gyi h&abreac;-gyi
and pha gyi &pspas;&abreac;-gyi for ‘that’, ‘yonder’, and, in WT, i , i po for ‘this’ and a for ‘that’; pha gyi occurs even in books.—
2. It is worth remarking that the distinction of the nearer and remoter relation is, even in common language, scrupulously observed. If reference is made to an object already mentioned, de is used; if to something following, 'di ; e.g. de skad ces smras so ‘that speech he said’, ‘thus he said’; 'di skad ces smras pa ‘this speech he said’, ‘he said thus, spoke the following words’.
28. Interrogative pronouns. They are su su ‘who?’; gang ga&ndota;, gha&ndota; ‘which?’; ci &cgrave;i ‘what?’; to these the indefinite article zhig is often added, su zhig etc. The two former can also assume the plural termination dag , su dag, gang dag .—In CT gang is frequently used instead of ci .
29. Relative pronouns. These are almost entirely wanting in the Tibetan language, and our subordinate relative clauses must be expressed by Participles and Gerunds, or a new independent sentence must be begun. The participle, in such a case, is treated quite as an adjective, being put either in the Genitive before the substantive, or, in the Nominative, after: 'gro ba'i tshong pa rnams ‘the merchants who would go (with him)’; nyag thag g.yu brgus pa ‘the cord on which turquoises are strung’; 'khyos ma mang po yong ba zhig
‘one who gets (unto whom come) many presents’. Cf. also 33. Only those indefinite sentences which in English are introduced by ‘he who’, ‘who ever’, ‘that which’, ‘what’ etc. can be adequately expressed in Tibetan, by using the interrogative pronouns with the participle (seldom the naked root) of the verb, or adding na (‘if—’ v. 41, A. 4.) to the latter. Instead of ci in this case ji is written more correctly. Thus: su la dam pa'i chos mchis pa bdag la ston par gyur na ‘if anybody who possesses the good faith teach it me’; khyod su 'gro ba dag kyang 'grogs te ‘when those of you who wish to go are assembled’; nor bu rin po che 'di ji 'dod pa thams cad char bzhin du 'bebs so ‘this jewel (cintāma&ndotb;i) will make come down like rain whatever is wished for’; khyod ci zer khyod ji smras pa bzhin du bya'o ‘whatever you may say and ask of me according to that I will act, or I will grant you whatever you ask’. bdag gis mthu ji yod pas rgya mtsho'i chu bcus te ‘having scooped the water of the sea with what force I have’; rin po che ji lta bu zhig rnyed pa bdag la bstan du gsol ‘I beg you to show me what sort of jewel you have found (got)’; rgang gye rjes gang rigs par gser gyi bye mar gyur to ‘his footprints, in what place soever they fell (v. lex. s. v. rigs ), became gold-sand’.
But the participle is treated as if no relative was preceding, thus sngar ji skad smras pa las ma zlogs so ‘he did not recede from (recall) the word he had spoken before’; vulg., WT, nga gang bsdad pa'i khang mig ‘the room where I sat’.
Chapter VI.
The Verb.
30. Introductory remarks. The Tibetan verbs must be regarded as denoting, not an action, or suffering, or condition of any subject, but merely a coming to pass, or, in other words, they are all impersonal verbs, like taedet, miseret etc. in Latin, or it suits etc. in English. Therefore they are destitute of what is called in our own languages the active and passive voice, as well as of the discrimination of persons, and show nothing beyond a rather poor capability of expressing the most indispensable distinctions of tense and mood. From the same reason the acting subject of a transitive verb must regularly appear in the Instrumental case, as the case of the subject of a neuter verb,—which, in European languages, is the Nominative—, ought to be regarded, from a Tibetan point of view, as an Accusative expressing the object of an impersonal verb, just as ‘poenitet me’ is translated by ‘I repent’. But it will perhaps be easier to say: The subject of a transitive verb, in Tibetan, assumes regularly the form of the instrumental, of a neuter verb that of the nominative which is the same as the accusative. Thus, ngas khyod rdung is properly:
rdung a beating happens, khyod regarding you, ngas by me = I beat you. In common life the object has often the form of the dative, khyod la , to facilitate the comprehension. But often, in modern talk as well as in the classical literature, the acting subject, if known as such from the context, retains its Nominative form. Especially the verba loquendi are apt to admit this slight irregularity.
31. Inflection of verbs. This is done in three different ways:
a) by changing the form of the root. Such different forms are, at most, four in number, which may be called, according to the tenses of our own grammar to which they correspond, the Present-, Perfect-, Future-, and Imperative-roots; e.g. of the Present-root gtong ba ‘to give’ the Perfect root is btang , the Future-root gtang , the Imperative root thong ; of 'tshag pa ‘to filter, bolt’ respectively: btsags tsag(s) (Ü: tsā), btsag tsag, tshog &tspas;sog. The Present root, which implies duration, is also occasionally used for the Imperfect (in the sense of the Latin and Greek languages) and Future tenses. It is obvious, from the above mentioned instances, that the inflection of the root consists partly in alterations of the prefixed letters (so, if the Perfect prefers the prefixed ba, the Future will have ga or retain the ba), partly in adding a final sa (to the Perfect and Imperative), partly in changing the vowel (particularly in the Imperative). But also the consonants of the root itself are changed
sometimes: so the aspirates are often converted in the Perfect and Future into their surds, besides other more irregular changes. Only a limited number of verbs, however, are possessed of all the four roots, some cannot assume more than three, some two, and a great many have only one. To make up in some measure for this deficiency:
b) some auxiliary verbs have been made available: for the Present tense yin , 'dug , lags and others, all of which mean ‘to be’ (§ 39); for the Perfect tshar , zin , song ; for the Future 'gyur , 'ong , and the substantive rgyu .
c) By adding various monosyllabic affixes, the Infinitive, Participles, and Gerunds are formed. These affixes as well as the auxiliary verbs are connected partly with the root, partly with the Infinitive, resp. its terminative, partly with the Participle.
Note. The spoken language, at least in WT, recognises even in four-rooted verbs seldom more than the Perfect root.
32. The Infinitive mood. The syllables pa pa or, after the final consonants nga _ra _la and vowels, ba wa are added to the root, whereby it assumes all the qualities and powers of a noun. In verbs of more roots than one, each of them can, of course, in this way be converted into a substantive, or, in other words, each tense has its Infinitive, except the Imperative. From one-rooted verbs the different Infinitives may be formed by the above mentioned auxiliaries: thus, the Inf. Perf., by adding yin pa to the Infinitive of
the verb in question, or tshar ba , zin pa , song ba to the root, and the Inf. Fut. by adding 'gyur ba to the Supine (terminative of the infinitive, 41. B) thus, mthong bar 'gyur ba visurum esse, visum iri.
Note. The spoken language uses, in WT almost exclusively, a termination pronounced &cgrave;as in Turig and Balti, &cgrave;es, &cgrave;e in Ladak, &cgrave;e in Lahoul etc., &jgrave;a in Kunawar, &sgrave;e in Tsa&ndota; etc., the etymology of which is doubtful, as it is not to be found in any printed book. Lamas in Ladak and Lahoul spell it ces .
33. The Participle.
1. This is in the written language entirely like the Infinitive yin pa ‘being’, gtong ba ‘giving’, btang ba ‘having given’.—
2. Whether the meaning is active or passive, however, can only be inferred from the context, e.g. btang ba'i dngul is of course ‘the money given’, but dngul btang ba'i mi ‘the man having given, or, that has given, the money’; the Tibetan participle means nothing but that the action or condition is connected in some way with a person or thing. But it is natural that in the present participle the active idea should be the more frequent one, as well as in the preterit the passive.—
3. In the instance of Intensive verbs (formed with byed pa 38.1) the usage of scientific authors has strictly connected the active sense with those formed with byed , as gtong byed to&ndota;-&jgrave;ed, to&ndota;-&jgrasa;&ebreve;&mlapos;, instead of gtong bar byed pa , ‘doing give, giving,
giver’, and the passive to those with bya , as gtong bya to&ndota; &jgrave;a, to&ndota; &jgrasa;a i.o. gtong bar bya ba ‘to be given’ (dandus), bya ba dang bya ba ma yin pa ston pa ‘to teach the things to be done and not to be done’ (Thgy.).—
4. In certain cases, especially with verbs that mean: to say, ask etc., the Participle is used before the words of the speech, where we should use the Imperfect: rgyal pos smras pa*** ‘the king said....’
Note. In the spoken language, of WT at least, the Participle is formed by mkhan , in the active sense as well as the passive (whereas in books this syllable occurs only in the meaning of the performer of an action, s. 12. 1.): dngul btang mkhan gyi mi &ndota;ul ta&ndota; &kspas;an-ni mi (s. 15, Note) ‘the man giving the money’, btang mkhan gyi dngul ‘the money given’. 'das zhag gon chas btsongs mkhan gyi bla ma ‘the lama who brought a coat for sale the other day’. bu mo rje btsun la sgo khung ston mkhan de ‘the girl who had shewn the door to his reverence’ (Mil.). The future participle is represented, just as in English, by the Infinitive (32, Note), so that ‘the sheep to be killed’, (in books gsod par bya ba'i lug or gsod bya'i lug ) is expressed, in the most Western provinces, by: sád &cgrave;as-si lug, Lad.: sád-&cgrave;es-si lug, Lah. etc.: sád &cgrave;eï lug, Tsa&ndota;: sö&mlapos;-&sgrave;ē-kyi lug gsod shes kyi lug , and, most like the classical language, in Kun.: sód &jgrave;&amaumb; lug.
34. The finite verb.
1. The principal verb of a sentence, which always closes it (48.) receives in written Tibetan in most cases a certain mark, by which the end of a period may be known. This is, in affirmative sentences, the vowel o (called by the grammarians: slar sdu ba ), in interrogative ones the syllable am. Before both the closing consonant of the verb is repeated, or, if it ends with a vowel, 'o and 'am are written. The Perfect of the verbs ending in na _ra _la , which formerly had a da as second final—da drag —, assume to and tam .—
2. These additional syllables are omitted
a) in imperative sentences,
b) in the latter member of a double question,
c) when the question is expressed already by an interrogative pronoun or adverb,
d) in coordinate members of a period, with the exception of the last one,
e) commonly, when the principal verb is the verb substantive yin , yod etc. (40. 1.).
Examples. a) song ‘go!’, 'di ru shog ‘come here!’.—b) mthong ngam mi mthong ‘do you see or not?’—c) de na su yod ‘who is there?’, nam bsleb ‘when did (he, you etc.) arrive?’.—d) khang pa shig_/mi bsad_/_grong khyer tshang ma med par byas so/ ‘the houses were destroyed, the men killed, the whole town annihilated’.—e) gtsang pa'i bye ma la gser yod/ ‘in the sand of the river is gold’.
Note. In conversation the o is generally omitted, and
the m of the interrogative termination dropped, so that merely the vowel a is heard, e.g. the question mthong ngam ‘do (you) see’ and the answer mthong ngo ‘(I) see’, are commonly spoken in WT: &tspas;o&ndota;-&ndota;a? &tspas;o&ndota;.
35. Present Tenses.
1. Simple Present Tense. This is the simple root of the verb, which will always be found in the dictionary; in WT, as mentioned above, of verbs with more than one root, only the Perfect root is in use; if, therefore, stress is laid on the Present signification, recourse must be had to one of the following compositions (s. 31. and Note). Thus, mthong ‘(I, thou, he etc.) see, seest etc.’, gtong ‘(I etc.) give’ through all persons; in the end of a sentence: mthong ngo*/_gtong ngo*/.
2. Compound Present Tenses.
a) 'dug (s. 40, 1) is added to the root: mthong 'dug ‘(I) see’, btang 'dug ‘(I) give’. This is common in the dialect of WT especially.—
b) The Participle connected with yin , mthong ba yin ‘I see’. In WT this, of course, is changed to mthong mkhan yin .—
c) One of the Gerunds (41, A) with yod or 'dug , as mthong ste (or nas or gi or zhing ), 'dug or yod ‘(I) see, am seeing’; it must, however, be remarked that both ways of expression, b) and c), are not very frequent.—
d) gin yod or 'dug is the proper form for the compound
English present: mthong gin 'dug ‘(I) am seeing’, 'bri gin 'dug ‘(I) am writing (just now)’.
36. Preterit Tenses.
1. Simple Preterit, Perfect or Aorist Tense; this is the Perfect root: btang , at the close of the sentence btang ngo*/ ‘gave, have given, was given’; in one-rooted verbs it has, of course, the same form as the present: mthong [(]ngo [)] ‘saw, have, or was, seen’. This is the usual narrative tense like the Greek Aorist or French Parfait défini.—
2. Compound Preterit Tenses.—
a) The root with song , btang song ‘have given, gave, was given’, mthong song ‘have seen, saw, was seen’; rarely met with in books, but in general use in the conversation of WT. In CT byung &jgrasa;u&ndota; is used in a similar way: khyis rmug byung ‘the dog has bitten’.—
b) The root with zin (more in books), or tshar (more in common language), the true Perfect as the tense of accomplished action: btang zin , btang tshar ‘have given etc.’, ‘the action of giving is past’, mi song tshar ‘the man has already left’.—
c) The Participle connected with yin occurs more frequently in the past sense than otherwise. Here, in the common talk of WT, pa is used, even in those cases where the books have ba , yi ge bkal pa yin yí-ge kál-pa yin, or, contracted, kál-pen, ‘the letter has been sent off’, in books: bkal ba yin (s. 11, Note), even gla btangs pa yin
la tá&ndota;s-pa yin, tá&ndota;s-pen, ‘the wages have been paid’ i.o. btang ba yin .—
d) Gerunds in te (WT) or nas (CT) with yod or 'dug (the same as 35. 2. c); also (in Ü Tsa&ndota; and later books) the mere Perfect root with yod , the te or nas being dropped: song yod ‘has gone’.
37. Future Tenses.
1. Simple Future. The Future-root, gtong [(]ngo [)] ‘shall, will give, be given’.—
2. Compound Future.
a) The auxiliary verb 'gyur ba (to grow, become) added to the Terminative case of the Infinitive: gtong bar 'gyur [(]ro [)] ‘shall, will give, be given’, mthong bar 'gyur [(]ro [)] ‘shall, will see, be seen’. This is the most common, and, together with the Simple Future and the Intensive (39.), ***bar bya'o , the only one in use with the early classical authors in all cases where a special Future-root is wanted, and even where this exists. It disappears, however, gradually from the literature of the later period, and is replaced by the two following compositions.—
b) rgyu yin connected with the root: mthong rgyu yin ‘shall, will see’, gtong rgyu yin ‘shall, will give’ etc. (rgyu is originally a substantive, meaning material, cause, occasion).—
c) the root with 'ong or yong , sleb yong ‘will arrive’, or, i.o. the root, the Term. Inf., sleb par 'ong .—Both b) and c) are even now in common
use in CT, whereas in WT:—
d) yin connected with the root is the general form: mthong yin &tspas;o&ndota; yin, vulg.: &tspas;ó&ndota;in ‘shall, will see’, btang yin tá&ndota;in, ‘shall, will give’, bkal yin kállin ‘will send’, tsha yin &cgrasa;a yin, &cgrasa;a'in, &cgrasa;än ‘will go’.—
e) In books the Participle with yin (35. 2. b, 36. 2 c) occurs sometimes also as Future.
38. Imperative mood.
1. This is usually the shortest possible form of the verb, which often loses its prefixed letters, though in some instances a final sa is added. In many verbs with the vowel a, and in some with e these vowels are changed into o, besides other alterations of the consonants. Particularly often the surds or sonants of the other tense-roots are changed to their aspirates in the Imperative. Thus, thong ‘give!’, from gtong ba ; ltos Ld: ltos, CT: t&omaumb; ‘look!’, from lta ba ; thob ‘throw!’, from 'debs pa . In one-rooted verbs it is, of course, like the Present, but it can always be sufficiently distinguished by adding the particle cig (shig or zhig , according to 13.). This is used in the classical literature indiscriminately in addressing the highest and the lowest persons (or, in other words, as well to command, as to pray), but according to the modern custom of CT only when addressing servants and inferior people.—
2. In forbidding, the Present-root is used with the negative particle ma , ma gtong ‘do not give!’, ma lta ‘do
not look!’, ma 'debs ‘do not throw!’—
3. In praying or wishing (Precative or Optative) either the same forms as under 1. are used, or the Imperatives of 'gyur ba ‘to come’ or 'ong ‘to come’ (the latter, shog , of a quite different root) are connected with the Termin. Infin. mthong bar gyur cig or shog cig ‘may (I, you, he etc.) see!’—
4. In none of the three a person is indicated, but it is natural that in commanding and forbidding the subject will be the second, sometimes the third person; in the precative also the first person can be understood.
Note. The common language of WT, acknowledging only the Perfect-root, changes nothing but the vowel: btong ‘give!’ from btang ces ; ltos ‘look!’ from lta ces ; btob ‘throw!’ from btab ces (Perf. of 'debs pa ). Instead of cig , which is not much used, btong (‘give!’) is often added to the roots of other verbs (s. 39), thus, bton btong ton to&ndota; ‘take out!’ from bton ces ('don pa ). Or the Imperative is paraphrased by dgos gos (Ld.), g&omaumb;, goi ‘must’, added to the root of the verb: bsad dgos ‘must be killed’.—In CT the changing of the vowel seems to be usually omitted, but the cig is more used. Here, also, the Perfect root is not so exclusively preferred.
39. Intensive verbs.
1. Very frequent in books is the
connection of the four-rooted verb byed pa (Pf. byas , Fut. bya , Imp. byos ) ‘to do’, elegantly bgyid pa (Pf. bgyis , Fut. bgyi , Imp. gyis ), respectfully mdzad pa (Imp. mdzod ) with the Term. Inf. of another verb, to intensify the action of the latter. By this means not only one-rooted verbs can be made to participate in the advantages of the four-rooted, as mthong bar byed ‘see’, mthong bar byas ‘saw’, mthong bar bya ‘shall, will see’, mthong bar byos ‘see!’, but also several other periphrastical phrases are gained for speaking more precisely than otherwise would be possible. The Future tense bya[(]'o[)]* serves, besides its proper notion of futurity, particularly to express the English auxiliaries ‘must, ought etc.’: thus, brjod par mi bya'o ‘must not be uttered, ought not to be uttered’, sometimes it may be translated by the Imperative mood. The spoken language, at least of WT, is devoid of this convenience, and possesses nothing of the kind except the above mentioned intensive form of the Imperative, formed by btong (s. 38., Note).—2. Another class of intensive verbs are formed by connecting two synonyms, as 'jigs skrag pa ‘to be afraid’, literally ‘to be fear-frightened’, and other similar ones.
40. Substantive and Auxiliary Verbs.
1. To be
a) yin pa , in elegant and respectful speech lags pa lag-pa, Ü: lā-pa (the latter word never used in WT) is the mere means
of connecting the attribute with its subject, as: mi 'di la dwags pa yin ‘this man is a Ladakee’, de khyed lags sam ‘is it you, Sir?’. Therefore the question su yin is to be understood ‘who are you’ or ‘who is he’ etc., the personal pronoun being often let to be guessed.—yin itself is often omitted in daily life in WT as well as in poetry, e.g. i khur ru mA lcin te ‘this load (is) very heavy’ WT. Negatively: ma yin , min vulg. man , resp. ma lags .—
b) yod pa yod-pa, yö&mlapos;-pa, eleg. mchis pa &cgrasa;ī-pa, resp. bzhugs pa &zgrave;ug(s)-pa, Ü: &zgrave;ū-pa, negat.: med , ma mchis , mi bzhugs means ‘to exist’, or ‘to be present’, ‘to be found at a place’, therefore the question su yod is to be understood: ‘Who is here? Who is there?’—yod and bzhugs pa are in general use, mchis pa is seldom heard. When connected with the Dative of a substantive it expresses the English ‘to have, to have got’, as: nga la dngul yod ‘I have money’; nga la zug yod ‘I have pain’. In this case the respectful term is not gzhugs pa but mnga' ba &ndota;a-wa: rgyal po la snyun mi mnga' 'am ‘has not the King an indisposition?’ i.e. ‘is Your Majesty ill?’.—
c) 'dug pa dug-pa (eleg. gda' ba is seldom heard), resp. bzhugs pa , ‘to be present, stay, be found at a place’; negat.
mi 'dug . Both 'dug pa and yod pa can be used instead of yin pa , though not this instead of them.—
d) red pa r&ebreve;&mlapos;-pa = 'dug pa , negat. ma red in Spiti and CT, seldom in books.—
e) mod pa mod-pa, mö&mlapos;-pa has a somewhat emphatical sense: ‘to be (something) in a high degree’, ‘to be (somehow) in plenty’. It occurs most frequently in the Gerund with kyi (41.), when it frequently has the sense of ‘though’, but never with a negative.—
f) snang ba na&ndota;-wa, originally ‘to appear, to be visible, extant’, negat. mi snang . Sometimes in books, and common in certain districts.—
g) In books the concluding o (34.) is, moreover, found to represent the verb ‘to be’ in all its meanings, and is capable of being connected with words of all classes besides verbs, e.g. dang po 'o ‘is the first’ = dang po yin . In a similar manner also the cig of the Imperative (38.) implies the verb ‘to be’.—
h) The Preterit root for all these verbs is song so&ndota; ‘was, has been’, and besides also ‘has gone, become’, which is its original meaning.—For the use of these verbs as auxiliaries s. 35. sq.
2. 'gyur ba originally ‘to be changed, turned into something’ then ‘to become, to grow’, auxiliary for the Future tense in the old classical language, as mentioned in 37. Since this can be considered as the intransitive or passive sense, opposed to byed pa ‘to make, render’, the connection
of 'gyur ba with the Term. Inf. of another verb must, in many cases, be rendered by the passive voice in our languages. In WT the verb cha ces &cgrasa;a-&cgrave;e ‘to go’ is used in the sense of ‘to become, to grow’. The Perfect root for both is song ‘(went), grew, became, has become, is’ (s. above).—In CT and later books 'byung ba is used instead.
3. ‘must’ is expressed by dgos pa ‘to be necessary’ (s. 38. Note). In WT this is used in a very wide sense for any possible modification of the notion of necessity: ‘I must, should, want to, ought’ and even ‘I will, wish, beg (for something)’ is nothing but nga la dgos ‘to me is necessary’ which may be, in the last mentioned case, rendered somewhat more politely by adding zhu &zgrave;u ‘pray!’ nga la a lu dgos zhu ‘I want potatoes, pray!’ is as much to say as ‘Will you kindly give me some potatoes’. In books and more refined language several other verbs are used in the same sense, viz. rigs pa ‘it is right to’ (usually with the Genit. Infin.), rung ba ‘it is meet, decent’, 'dod pa ‘to wish, desire’, both with the Supine; dga' ba ‘to like’ with the Dat. Inf. The popular substitute of the last, especially in use in WT, is 'thad pa , of similar meaning, added to the root.
41. Gerunds and Supines. We retain these terms, employed by former grammarians, but observe that they do not refer to the form, but to the meaning, as well as that Gerund is not to be understood in the same signification
as in Latin, but as the Gérondif of some French grammarians, or what Shakespeare calls Past conjunctive participle in Hindi. These forms are of the greatest importance in Tibetan, being the only substitutes for most of those subordinate clauses which we are accustomed to introduce by conjunctions. They are formed by the two monosyllabic affixes te (so after the closing consonants na _ra _la sasa ); de after dede , ste after ga _nga _ba mama and vowels and cing (shing or zhing according to the same rule as cig 13.), both of which are added to the root, or by the terminations mentioned in 15. as composing the declension of nouns, which are added partly to the root, partly to the Infinitive or Participle.
A. Gerunds. All the following forms can be rendered by the English Participle ending in ing, but the more accurate distinctions must be expressed by various conjunctions.
1. te (de etc.), the most frequent of all these endings. It is added to the Present-root as well as to the Perfect-root: gtong ste ‘giving’, btong ste ‘having given’, and stands for all clauses beginning with when, as, since, after etc. Also in the spoken language of WT it is used most frequently.—Examples: phru gu chus khyer te shi'o ‘the child, having been carried away by the water, died’; rgyal po shi ste rgyal sras kyis rgyal sa bzung ngo ‘the king having died, the prince occupied
the throne (king's-place)’; chu chen po zhig de ru yod de 'grul mi thub bo ‘as there is a great water, we cannot go’.
2. cing (shing etc.), of a similar sense, chiefly used for smaller clauses within a large one, mi dga' zhing khros te ‘when, being displeased, he became angry’, or ‘growing displeased and angry’. Often it denotes two actions going on at the same time, or two states of a thing existing together, and then can only be translated by ‘and’, thus, mtha' med cing mu med ‘without end and boundary’; sha la za zhing khrag la 'thung ba ‘to eat flesh and drink blood’The objects of za ba and 'thung ba often assume the dative-sign, cf. English ‘to feed on’.. It stands also in a causal sense: ‘by doing etc.’, as: nya bshor zhing 'tsho'o ‘(we) live by catching fish’. These two (1. and 2.) can also, like the closing o, as mentioned in 40. 1. g, be added to every class of words, in the sense of being: khyod rigs che zhing mtho ba ste ‘as you are high(-born), being of a great family’. In conversation, cing is scarcely ever heard.
3. nas (from, or after, doing something) in temporal clauses with ‘after, when, as’; practically it is very much like te , and often alternating with it. In most cases, in speaking always, it is added to the root, seldom to the infinitive.
—Examples. nam langs nas song ‘when the night had risen (viz. at daybreak) he went’; lang nas song ‘after you will have risen, go!’ de mthong nas skad phyung ste ngus so ‘when I saw that, raising clamour, I wept’.
4. na ‘in (doing something)’ again for clauses with ‘since, when, as’, but in most cases by far for ‘if’ and conditional ‘when’: 'gro na ‘if, or, when (I) go, or went’; shi tshar na ‘when, after (he) has died’, ‘if he is already dead’; shi na ‘if (he) die, should die’, ‘if (he) died’, ‘when (he) dies’; byed na ‘if ... do, did’; bya na ‘if ... were to do’. It is added to the root, seldom to the infinitive, and as common in talking as in books.
5. la is of more various use. When added to the root, it is very much like cing , which it replaces in the conversational language of CT (where the first example of 2. would be, ma dga' la khros te ), but does not occur so often except in imperative or precative sentences, when it is added to the Imperative root of the subordinate verb, just like other gerunds: song la ltos ‘going look!’, ‘go and look!’ long la song ‘rise and go!’. This particle, like the above-mentioned, implies the verb ‘to be’, especially when added to adjectives denoting a personal quality. mi sdug la thung ngu yin te ‘being ugly and short’; dbyibs legs shing lta na sdug la mdzes
pa ‘pretty, being of a good figure and nice to behold’. When added to the Infinitive, it denotes:
a) of course, the real Dative, or the usual meanings of the postposition la with a substantive; thus, gsod pa la dga' ba ‘to rejoice at killing, be fond of killing’.
b) nearly the same as te or ‘as’ in English, e.g. lam gyi bar du lha rten zhig yod pa la shing rta las bab bo ‘as there was an idol-shrine in the middle of the way, (she) alighted from (her) chariot’; rgyal po nyin re bzhin du der khrus byed du 'gro ba la ‘as the king went there daily to bathe’; 'jig rten gyi nang na mi 'ong ba la 'di ru 'ong ba ci yin ‘as (it) does not occur in the (whole) world, what is (its) occurring here, or, how is it that it occurs here?’. Finally, in the language of common life la is added to the repeated root in order to express the English ‘while, whilst’: ngas sha gtub gtub la khyod kyis shing khyong &ndota;&amaumb; &sgrave;a tub-túb-la &kspas;yód-dī (15., Note) &sgrave;i&ndota; &kspas;yo&ndota; WT, or khyod kyis shing bkur shog &kspas;yö&mlapos;-kyī &sgrave;i&ndota; kur-&sgrave;og CT ‘while I am cutting the meat into pieces, bring you (some) wood’.
6. las added only to the Infinitive, literally ‘out of (the doing)’. This may mean
a) ‘after’, nyal ba las lang ba ‘to rise from lying, after having lain’; dur na zhag gsum 'dug pa las dur nas byung ‘after having been three days in
the grave (I) came out of the grave’.—
b) ‘while’, in which case the root of the verb may be repeated, as: song song ba las bram ze zhig dang phrad do ‘out of my walking i.e. when walking along, (I) met with a brahman’; nga sha gtub gtub pa las khyod kyis shing bkur te shog (the above mentioned example (s. la ) translated into classical language);
c) also the English ‘being about to’ is, in books, often expressed by this Gerund: nang du song ba las sgo bcad do ‘when (I) was about to enter, the door was shut’; shi ba las phyir sos par gyur to ‘when (I) was going to die, (I) was restored to life again’. Which of the three is the real meaning, will in most cases be clear from circumstances. This gerund is not used in talking, at least in WT.
7. kyis (gyis etc.) or kyi (gyi etc.), or the Instrumental and Genitive cases of the root, mean
a) ‘by doing something’ or ‘because’, e.g. dgos kyis 'dong ngo ‘we come (here), because it is necessary’. kho mos grogs bu yis snying ma chung zhig ‘since I am resolved to help you, do not be depressed!’ This, originally, is a function of the Instrumental only, but in later times the other cases also are used in this meaning.—
b) more frequently they are used adversatively, ‘though’, especially when connected with mod (40. 1. e), ces smras mod kyis cis yid ches par 'gyur ‘though (you) did
say so, by what shall (I) believe (it)?’ In other cases it may be left untranslated when the next sentence will commence with ‘but’: zas bzang po mi 'dod kyis zas tha mal pa zos so ‘not liking delicate food, he ate vulgar food’ or ‘he did not like d. f., but preferred v. f.’. This Gerund is scarcely used in talking, at least in WT.
8. pas (bas ), the Instrumental of the Infinitive, ‘by (doing something)’ is, of course, the proper expression for ‘because’, but also very often used indiscriminately for te or nas only for the sake of varying the mode of speaking: shin tu dka' ba yin pas ‘because it is very difficult’; ltas pas ‘when (he) looked’.
9. Also gin the proper use of which has been shewn above (35. 2. d.) must be mentioned once more as it occurs in a similar sense to cing , smon lam 'debs gin song zhig ‘walk on praying (preces faciendo)!’; brang brdung gin ngus pas ‘beating (her own) breast and weeping’.
B. Supines. They are expressed simply by the Terminative Case of the Infinitive or of the Root, mthong bar or thong du ‘to see’. In many instances the use of either is optional, in others one is preferred.
1. Their use is: with adjectives like the Latin supine in u, e.g. bslab tu dka' ba ‘difficult to learn’; with verbs expressing ‘to go, to send’ etc.,
also ‘to pray’ etc. like that in um: len tu song ‘go to fetch’, gnang du gsol ‘(I) beg (you) to permit,—for permission’. In these cases the root is most common, but the Inf. bslab par , or gnang bar , len par may also be used.
2. Another use of the Supine is
a) with verbs of sensation and, less frequently, with those of declaration, where we use sentences with ‘that’ or the Participle or Infinitive: ma 'ong bar mthong nas ‘seeing (his) mother coming’ (instead of which, however, 'ong ba may be said as well); ***ba'i dus la bab par shes nas ‘knowing that the time of ...ing had arrived’ (lit: ‘that it had come down to the time’); rgyal po'i bu yin par dran nas ‘remembering him to be the king's son’ or ‘that he was...’.—
b) in an adverbial sense, when we say ‘so that’, especially in negative sentences, ‘so that not’, ‘without ...ing’, sus kyang ma tshor bar ‘so that nobody may (did) perceive it’, or ‘without anybody perceiving it’.
Note 1. The modern language of WT uses in the first instance (B. 1.) either the simple Infinitive, bslab ces khag po (or dkag po ), or the same with la , bslab ces la khag po , or with phyi la (for the phyir of the books s. 7. 2.), bslab ces phyi la khag po ; in the second either the same forms, or a particular one, which consists in repeating the final consonant
of the root with the vowel a, to which also la may be added: thus, len na song , khyod rang la thug ga la yongs song ‘(I) have come to meet you’; in the third, the direct Imperative adding zhu for the sake of civility, dgongs zhu ‘pray permit!’
In the case of B. 2., instead of ma 'ong bar mthong nas , the expression in common use will be a ma yong or yong nga mthong nas ; instead of sus kyang ma tshor bar , either the same form, ma tshor ra , or the Gerund, ma tshor te .—In CT those examples would respectively, stand thus, bslab tu or bslab ba or bslab pa'i don du dkag po láb-tu, láb-ba (sounding almost lă-wa), láb-päb; &dspas;öb;n-&dspas;u kag-po; in the third instance a peculiar word, ‘rog’, is used, which is said to be originally the same as grogs (rogs ) ‘friend, assistant’, and serves now as the respectful substitute of cig , Particle of the Imperative, gnang rog ‘pray permit!’, ster rog ‘pray give!’ Instead of ma tshor ra etc. the most usual form in CT will be the simple Participle, ma shes pa .
Note 2. All the forms, of course, where pa or ba are met with might in certain cases belong to the Participle, and not to the Infinitive.
Note 3. The reader will have missed any mention of tenses of the class of Pluperfect, Past Future etc., and,
indeed, there exists no form of the kind, and they can only be rendered by a Gerund, e.g. yi ge bris zin nas bkal song ‘when (he) had written the letter, (he) sent (it) off’; yi ge bris zin nas bkal bar 'gyur (WT: bkal yin , CT: bkal rgyu yin ) ‘when (he) shall have written the letter, (he) will send (it) off’. Neither have the Conditional or Subjunctive any special form. Thus, e.g., 'di ma byas na mi 'tsho'o ‘if we did not do that, we could not live’ (i.e. we cannot earn our sustenance in any other manner); ci'i phyer khyod zer ba ni mi nyan ‘why should not I hear (grant) what you say (your wish)?’; brda ma bkrol zhing rtags ma mthong na mi rtogs par 'dug ‘if (you) had not explained it, and (we) had not seen the signs, we would not have understood it’; mis mi rnyed pas sprul pa cig btag dgos ‘as a man would not find it, I must send an emanation’; vulg., WT, i zug thag ring ma yin na nga'i rtsar 'gro du yong yin ‘if the distance was not so great, they would come to me (visit me)’. Here may be added, that also the intention of, or attempt at, doing something is expressed by the simple verb: thus, bdag gis bkag yang ma btub kyis ‘though I did try to hinder him, I could not’; bdag gi nye gnas chur mchongs pa mthong nas/_chur ma phyin par rdzu 'phrul gyi mthus blangs so ‘as he saw his own disciple
on the point of springing into the water (and that he had sprung off the bank), he held him back by the force of his magic, so that he did not touch the water’ (s. 41. B. 2. b.). Especially the gerunds in las (41. A. 6.) have often this meaning: bdag srog dang bral ba las srog gi skyabs byas so ‘when I was about to be parted from life, he saved it’; sbrul khros nas gdug pa phyung pa las yang 'di snyams bsams so ‘the snake, having become angry, though she intended (or: had at first int.) to let out her poison, reflected thus’. As will be seen from these examples, the action, in such cases, is thought to have begun in fact.

Chapter VII.
The Adverb.
42. We may distinguish three classes of adverbs: 1. Primitive adverbs. 2. Adverbs formed from Adjectives. 3. Adverbs formed from Substantives or Pronouns.
1. Very few Primitive Adverbs occur; the most usual are: da ‘now’, nam ‘when’, sang (books and CT) or tho re (WT) ‘to morrow’, and a few similar ones; yang ‘again’, and the two negatives mi and ma , the latter of which is used in prohibitive sentences, and with a past tense, as mi gtong ‘(I) do not give’, mi gtang ‘(I) shall not give’, but: ma btang ‘did not give’, ma gtong (WT: ma btang ) ‘do not
give!’ The verbs yin , lags , mchis , red have always ma instead of mi before them (40.). Another particle of this kind, of a merely formal value, is ni , which is added to any word or group of words in order to single it out and distinctly separate it from everything that follows. It is, therefore, often very useful in lessening the great indistinctness of the language, especially so when separating the subject from the attribute: mi de ni la dwags pa yin ‘that man is a Ladakee’. (There is scarcely an adequate word to be found in our modern languages, but the Greek ge, or men—de—, are very similar.) In talking it is seldom heard, and, when used, in WT pronounced: ning .
2. Adverbs may be formed from any Adjective by putting it in the Terminative case. bzang po ‘good’, bzang por ‘well’; rab ‘principal’, rab tu ‘principally, very’; drag po ‘violent’, drag por or drag tu ‘violently’.
3. Nearly all the local Adverbs are formed from Substantives or Pronouns with some local Postposition: gong ‘the place (space) above, upper part’, gong na ‘above’, gong tu ‘upwards’, gong nas ‘from above (downwards)’; 'di ‘this’, 'di na ‘in this, here’, 'di ru , 'dir ‘hither, here’ (cf. 15.), 'di nas ‘hence’; de ‘that’, de na ‘there’, de ru, der ‘thither, there’, de nas ‘from there, thence, then, after that’.
Note. In talking the simple adjective is used, mostly, instead of its adverb (2. class): mgyogs pa for —par ‘quickly, soon’.
Chapter VIII.
The Postposition.
