zla ba brgyad pa nas ‘from (after) the eighth month’.
thog ma nas (books and CT), WT: mgo ma nas ‘from the beginning’.
//_las _//
dkar khung las ‘from the window, through the window’.
'khor ba las 'grol ba , vulg: ***nas bsgral ba ‘to deliver from the circulation (transmigration)’.
pa gu las khang pa rtsig pa , WT: nas , Tsang: pa gu'i nang rtsig pa ‘to build a house out of brick (Ts: a house of brick)’.
mdo za ma tog las ‘from the sūtra Zamatog’.
slob ma las gcig (vulg: slob ma'i nang nas gcig ) ‘one of (from among) the pupils’.
kun las mkhas pa (books and CT), WT: tshang ma'i sang mkhas pa ‘wiser than all, the wisest, most skilful of all’.
gnyis las ma lus so ‘more than two are not left’.
nga las mi 'dug ‘more than myself are not’.
Besides these dang ‘with’ is to be mentioned as Simple Postposition: thus, khye'u dang smras te , WT: khyog thong dang lab ste ‘speaking (conversing) with the youth’; nga dang ‘with me’, or, in fuller form, nga dang lhan gcig tu , nga dang bcas su vulg: nga dang mnyam po ‘together with me’. In WT it is even used for the instrumental when the real instrument (tool) of an action is meant, e.g. rgyal pos blon po ral gris bsad so in books, but WT: ral gri dang bsad ‘the king killed the minister with the sword’. It is, moreover, added to many Adjectives and Verbs, when we use the Accusative or Dative or other Prepositions, e.g. de dang 'dra ba ‘like (with) that, similar to that’. With an Infinitive it denotes the synchronism of the action with another one, nyi ma shar ba dang ‘with the sun rising, at sunrise’; gnyid song ba dang ‘with (on) their going to sleep, when they went to sleep’; ces smras pa dang khyim du song ‘(with) saying so he went home’ or also ‘he said so, and went home’. Often it is found with
an Imperative, without any perceptible signification, if it is not to be regarded as a substitute for cig (38): da zo dang ‘now eat!’ For its use as a conjunction see the next chapter.
2. Compound Postpositions. These may conveniently be grouped in two classes:
a) Local Compound Postpositions, which are virtually the same as the Local Adverbs specified in 42. 3.: thus, nang na ‘in (the midst of)’, nang du ‘into’ also ‘in’, nang nas ‘from, out of’. The most usual ones will be seen in the following examples:
rdzing gi nang na (or du ) khrus byed pa ‘to bathe in a pond’.
chu'i nang du zhugs ‘he entered into the water’ (both in books and common talk).
lha'i nang na gtso bo ‘the lord among the gods’.
khang pa'i nang nas 'thon (or 'byung ) vulg. ‘(he) comes (emerges) out of the house’.
sgo'i gong tu (or na , or la ) ‘above the door’ (books and vulg., but more usual in WT: sgo ltag , CT sgo thod ).
yab kyi gong tu 'das , vulg.: yab kyi sngan la (or lngun la , CT also gdong la ‘he died before his father’.
pad+ma'i steng du (or na , or thog tu , or kha ru ) bzhugs pa , vulg., in WT: kha thog la (kha thod la ), CT: dgeng la ‘to sit on a lotus-flower’.
sgo'i 'gram du (or la , or na ) (books and talk) ‘beside, near the door’.
shing gi drung du , vulg.: mdun la , rtsa na , rtsar ‘under a tree’ (literally: ‘in front, by the side, of a tree’).
zhal che pa'i drung du (mdun du ) 'khrid pa ‘to take before the judge’.
zla ba brgyad kyi rjes la CT, rting la WT ‘after eight months’.
zla ba gnyis kyi sngan la (or sngun la ) vulg. ‘before two months, two months ago’.
sa'i 'og tu gter sbed pa books and CT, WT: sa'i 'og la gter sba ba ‘to hide a treasure below the ground’.
sa'i 'og nas 'byung ba CT, WT: sa'i yog nas 'thon pa ‘to emerge, come out, from below the ground’.
chu'i pha rol na books and CT, in CT also: phar phyogs pa , WT: phar kha la , phar ngos la ‘beyond the water, river’.
chu'i tshu rol na books and CT, WT: tshur kha la ‘on this side of the water’.
zhag gsum du (or nas ) thang de'i pha rol tu phyin par 'gyur ro , CT: pha rol tu sleb yong , WT: phar kha la sleb yin ‘in (after) three days he will arrive beyond this plain, will have crossed it’.
khang pa'i phyogs bzhi ru ‘in the four regions of the house, roundabout’.
yul de'i phyogs la song ‘go in the direction of, towards, that village’.
lo bdun gyi bar du , CT: lo bdun thug [(]pa [)], WT: ***tshug pa ‘for seven years’.
'di nas de'i bar du , CT: 'di nas de thug pa , WT: i nas a tshug pa ‘from this to that’.
nga nyung ti ru cha ces tshug pa WT: ‘till I go to Kullu’.
b) General Compound Postpositions, expressive of the general relations of things and persons. They are formed in the same manner as the Local ones, from substantives, adjectives, and even verbs. Their use may be learned from the following examples:
nga'i phyir [(]du [)] or don du books and CT, WT: nga'i phi la ‘for me, in my behalf, for my sake, on my account’.
nad de ni ci'i phyir byung , WT: ci'i phi la yongs , CT: gang gi ron du byung ‘for what reason has that illness come? what is the cause of etc.?’.
sems can thams cad kyi don du ‘in behalf of all living beings’.
shing gi tshab la rdo (WT: rdo ba ) btong ‘give (apply) stone instead of wood’.
bzhin du ‘according to, like, as’—rgyal po'i bka' bzhin du byas te ‘doing according to the word of the king’; de
bzhin du ‘according to that, like that, thus, so’; snga ma bzhin du ‘as formerly, as before’; instead of it the dialect of WT uses nang ltar , generally with the Genitive, thus the last example there would be: sngan ma'i nang ltar .
ltar ‘like’, ri ltar ‘like a hill’; 'di ltar , de ltar ‘like this, like that, thus, so’, ci ltar , CT: gang ltar ‘like what? how? in what manner?’.
In the dialect of WT mtshogs or mtshogs se is used instead (which is a corruption of mtshongs , occurring in books with the same meaning): thus, ri mtshogs se ‘like a hill’; 'di mtshogs , de mtshogs ‘thus’; or zug (properly tsug ), i zug , a zug ‘thus’, ga zug ‘how?’.
Chapter IX.
The Conjunction.
44. The written language possesses very few, the spoken still fewer, Conjunctions, most of which are coordinative. The common word for ‘and’ is dang which we have seen above in the sense of ‘with’, gser dang*/_dngul dang*/_lcags la sogs pa ‘gold and silver and iron and collection (i.e. and so on)’, though the position of the &sgrave;ad (10.) after the word dang shows that it is always considered as belonging to the preceding member of the sentence, similar, in
this respect, to the Latin ‘que’; nor can it in any case begin a sentence. Very seldom, and only in later literature, it appears as combining two verbs, if not, indeed, the root ought to be regarded there as abbreviation for the infinitive. Further: yang ‘also, too’. When belonging to a single word or notion it is put after it in an enclitical way like ‘quoque’ in Latin. It is changed according to the termination of the preceding word, into kyang after ga _da _ba _sa This is not very carefully observed even in good mscr. and prints, where yang will occur sometimes after ga etc., and kyang after the other consonants and even after vowels., into 'ang often after vowels (cf. 6). Thus: bu zhig kyang khrid de ‘taking also a son (with him)’. When repeated, it has the signification of Latin ‘et—et—’, ma yang shi/_bu yang shi'o// ‘both mother and son died’. Often, especially in negative sentences, it means ‘even’, gcig kyang ma rnyed do ‘even one (they) did not find—not even one’. This is the only means for expressing ‘none, no, nothing’, mi su (or gang ) yang ma 'ongs (resp. yongs ) ‘nobody came’; de na ci yang (ci'ang , or cang ) med ‘there is nothing’ (cf. 29). When combined with verbs, btsal yang ma rnyed do ‘even searching (they) did not find’, it serves as another expression for ‘though’ or also ‘but’ (s. 41. A. 7. b): thus, ‘though they searched, they etc.’ or ‘they searched, but they etc.’. Standing
for itself (not leaning on the preceding word) it means ‘again, once more’ (when it is to be regarded as adverb), der yang 'khams nas ‘there (I) fainting once more etc.’. In the beginning of a sentence it is ‘and, again, moreover’, and may occasionally be rendered by ‘however, but’. yang na , ‘or’; repeated, yang na****_yang na**** ‘either—or—’.—‘Or’ is expressed also by the interrogative affix of the finite verb (34. 1.), 'am etc., gser dngul 'am/_zangs kyi bum po ‘a bottle of gold, silver, or copper’.—'on kyang ‘nevertheless, but’, vulg: yin kyang occurs much less frequently in Tibetan than in the European languages.
The only Subordinate Conjunctions are:
1. gal te ‘if’, introducing conditional sentences ending in na (41. A. 4). But, as the conditional force really rests on the closing na , the initial gal te may be put or omitted at pleasure;
2. ci ste ‘but if’; gal te nus na**** ‘if I can ...’, ci ste mi nus na ‘but if not ...’; this last is found only in books.
Chapter X.
The Interjection.
45. The most common Interjection is kye , or, repeated, kye kye ‘oh!, alas!’ used also before the Vocative. The language of common life uses instead: wa wa, or wa'i wä.
Chapter XI.
Derivation.
46. Derivation of Substantives. As most of what belongs under this head has already been mentioned in 11. and 12. only the formation of abstract nouns remains to be spoken of.
1. The unaltered adjective may be used as an abstract noun, especially with the article ba , as: grang ba dro bar 'gyur ‘the cold is changed into warmth’.—To this may be added the pronoun nyid (grang ba nyid ‘ipsum frigidum’); but this is used scarcely anywhere else than in metaphysical treatises, from whence a few expressions, such as stong pa nyid ‘the vacuum, the absolute rest in deliverance from existence’ have become more generally known.—
2. In the case of two correlative ideas existing, frequently the compound of both is used, esp. in common talk, che chung ‘size’ (lit. ‘large and small’), sbom phra ‘thickness’ (‘thick and thin’), e.g. che chung ni yungs 'bru tsam ‘the size as much as a mustard-seed’.—
3. khyad ‘difference’ (or, sometimes, tshad , tshod ‘measure’) is added, mtho khyad ‘height’, phyug khyad ‘wealth, riches’.—
4. Mental qualities are in most cases paraphrased by sems , or blo with a genitive, bzod pa'i sems ‘mind of suffering, enduring, i.e. patience’, mkhas pa'i blo ‘wise mind, wisdom, skill’; dga' ba'i sems ‘mind of rejoicing,
joy’ (vulg: sems dga' mo ), dad pa'i sems ‘mind of belief (also ‘a believing mind’), faith’.—
5. Diminutives are formed by adding the termination 'u , often with an alteration of the preceding vowel: rta ‘horse’, rte'u ‘little horse, foal’; mi ‘man’, mi'u ‘little man, dwarf’; rdo ‘stone’, rde'u ‘small stone, calculus’. If a word ends with a consonant, only u is added, and a new syllable formed: lug ‘sheep’, lu gu ‘lamb’.
47. Derivation of Adjectives.
1. Possessive adjectives are regularly expressed by adding the syllable can , or the phrase dang ldan pa , abridged ldan to any substantive, mgo can ‘having a head’; mi mgo can ‘having the head of a man’; skra can ‘having hair, (long-)haired’; rig pa can , rig pa dang ldan pa ‘possessing knowledge, learned, wise’; dang ldan pa is never heard in common talk in WT.—
2. Adjectives of appurtenance are generally expressed by the genitive of the substantive, gser gyi ‘of gold, golden’; sha'i mig ‘the eye of flesh, the carnal, bodily eye’, oppos.: shes rab kyi mig ‘the eye of knowledge, spiritual eye’.—
3. Negative, or privative adjectives are formed in several ways:
a) by the simple negative mi , mi 'os pa ‘unworthy’; mi rung ba ‘unfit’; mi thos pa ‘unheard of’.
b) by adding med ‘without’,
mgo med ‘headless’; skyon med ‘faultless’.
c) by adding the verb bral [(]ba [)] ‘separated from’, lus dang bral ba , lus bral ‘separated from the body, bodiless’.—
4. The English adjectives in -able, -ible are expressed by rung ba ‘to be fit’, added to the Supine, or to the simple Root, 'thang du rung ba , 'thung rung ‘fit for drinking, drinkable’, vulgo: 'thung nyan (from nyan pa ‘to be able’), 'thung chog (chog ‘permitted, lawful’).
Part III.
Syntax.
48. Arrangement of words.
1. The invariable rule is this: in a simple sentence all other words must precede the verb; in a compound one all the subordinate verbs in the form of gerunds or supines, and all the coordinate verbs in the form of the root, each closing its own respective clause, must precede the governing verb (examples s. below).—
2. The order in which the different cases of substantives belonging to a verb are to be arranged, is rather optional, so that e.g. the agent may either precede or follow its object. Local and temporal adverbs or adverbial phrases are, if possible, put at the head of the sentence.—
3. The order of words belonging to a substantive is this: 1. The Genitive, 2. the governing Substantive, 3. the Adjective (unless this is itself put, in the genitive, before; 16), 4. the Pronoun, 5. the Numeral, 6. the indefinite Article: thus, nga'i bu mo chung ngu 'di ‘this my little daughter’; gos dmar po zhig ‘a red gown’; gos dmar po or dmar po'i gos ‘the red gown’; rgyal khams chen po 'di gsum ‘these three great kingdoms’. Adverbs precede the word they belong to: shin tu chen po ‘very great’; shin tu mgyogs par shog ‘come very quickly’.—
4. In correlative sentences (cf. 29) the Relative precedes the Demonstrative: gang yod pa de thong zhig ‘what there is, give!’ i.e. ‘give whatever you have’, and in comparative sentences the thing with which another is compared, ordinarily precedes this (cf. 17).
49. Use of the cases. As the necessary observations about the instrumental have been made in 30, about the other cases and postpositions partly in 15, partly in 43, it is only the Accusative, that requires a few words more, as it is very often used absolutely (as in Greek).
a) Acc. temporalis: mtshan mo ‘at night’; gson po'i tshe ‘during (his etc.) lifetime’; de'i tshe, de dus ‘at that time’; nyi ma gcig bslabs nas ‘having studied for one day, after one day's study’.—
b) Acc. modalis: dbyibs zlum pa ‘regarding the size, round’; gting zab khyad khru brgyad pa ‘regarding the depth, eight cubits’ (cf. 12); kha dog du ba lta bur yod pa ‘regarding colour, being like smoke’ (cf. 50, 1, a); rigs mthun pa ‘with regard to (his) birth, equal’ i.e. ‘of equal birth’. Here ni (42. 1) is very often employed: dbyibs ni zlum pa etc. Nearly in all cases, however, postpositions may be added, and in talking they are preferred to the simple Accusative: mtshan mo la , mtshan la , de'i tshe na , dbyibs la etc.
50. Simple Sentences.—
1. Affirmative sentences.—
a) the attribute being a noun, the verb: to be, become, remain etc.; mi 'di ni mkhas pa yin ‘this man is wise’; 'di ni mi mkhas pa zhig yin ‘this is a wise man’. When the verb is 'gyur ba (to become), gnas pa (to remain) etc. the attribute must be put in the Terminative: skra dkar por gyur to ‘(his) hair became white’; rgyal po yi dam la brtan par gnas so , vulg: brtan po gnas pa yin ‘the king remained steadfast on his vow’; in some special cases this may take place, even if the verb is simply ‘to be’: lus gzugs thams cad mi 'dra ste/_rkang pa 'ba' zhig khra bor 'dug go ‘while his whole shape was like a man's, his foot only was piebald’.
b) the attribute being any other verb: rgya nag yul gyi rgyal po snga ma zhig gis yul de'i byang phyogs su lcags ri shin tu chen po zhig brtsigs so ‘an ancient king of China built a very large wall in the north of that country’.
2. Interrogative sentences.—
a) simple: khyod kyi bu khang pa la 'dug gam ‘is your son in the house?’; de ru su yod ‘who is there?’; ci la yong ‘what do you come for?’, ‘what do you want?’.—rin tsam W (rin ga tshod C) ‘how much (is) the price?’.
Besides the affix am the later literature and the conversational
language of CT has the accentuated interrogative particle e &ebreac;, immediately before the verb: thabs e yod &tspas;ab &ebreac; yö&mlapos; ‘is there any means...?’; las 'di byed e nus l&amaumb; di &jgrave;&ebreve;&mlapos; &ebreac; n&umaumb; ‘can you do this work?’.
The form of a question is also used to express uncertain suppositions (likely to become realized), as: rjed pa srid dam ‘is forgetting possible?’ for ‘he may possibly have forgotten it’; shi ba yin nam ‘won't he die?’; 'di bdud ma yin nam ‘this (apparition) is not the devil, I hope?’.
b) double: nang na yod dam med ‘is (he) within or not?’; bdag la sbyin du rung ngam mi rung ‘is it agreeable (to you i.e. do you consent) to give me (your son) or not?’; nga 'ongs pa mi dga' 'am ci nyes ‘are you sorry at my arrival, or what (else) is the matter (with you—because you weep)?’.
3. Imperative and Optative or Precative sentences do not require any additional remarks besides what is said in 38.
51. Compound Sentences. After having examined in 41 the different gerunds as the constituent parts of compound sentences, a few examples will suffice for illustration.
1. Compound sentences, for the most part coordinative: rgyal pos khrims bca' ste'cha' ba , perf. bca' ‘to make’ esp. ‘institute,
arrange’; gerund./_bzang i.o. bzang po la .la bya dga' ster/_ngan pa la
chad pa gcod‘to cut’, but chad pa (or pas ) gcod pa ‘to inflict a punishment’./_bre srang gtan la phabgtan la 'bebs pa ‘to set in order, arrange’; perf. phab ./_mi la yi ge bslabs soslob pa , perf. bslabs ‘to learn’.// ‘The king having given a law, the good were given rewards, the bad punished, measures and weights arranged, and people taught letters (i.e. reading and writing)’.
2. subordinate sentences: der 42. 3.bud med gnyis shig indefin. art. after numerals s. 13.bu gcig la rtsod de/_rgyal po blo Accus. modal., 49.mkhas pas brtag nas rtog pa , perf. brtag .'di skad ces 27. 2.bsgo'o/_/khyod gnyis kyis bu'i lag pa re re nas bzung ste/_drongs la 'dren pa , perf. drangs , imp. drongs ; cf. 41. 5.gang gis thob pa 29.bu khyer zhig 'khyer ba , perf. and imp. khyer .ces bsgo ba dang 43. 1./_bu'i ma ma yin pa des ni 42. 1.bu la snying rje med pas 41. 8.snad kyis the object of the fear usually in the instrumental.mi dogs te/_mthu je yod par termin. of inf. used as adverb, 41. B. 2. b.drangs so/_/bu'i ma gang yin pa de ni bu la byams pas snad kyis dogs te/_stobs kyis thub kyang 44.drag tu 42. 2.
ma 42. 1.drangs so/_/rgyal pos drag tu drangs pa de la/_'di ni khyod kyi bu ma yin te/_bud med cig shos shos ‘other’, almost always with the indefin. article; 13. fin.kyi bu yin pas nana is sometimes pleonastically added to pas (bas ), to strengthen its meaning./_drang por 43.2.smros shig smra ba , perf. smras , imp. smros .ces smras pa dang*/_dal gyis drangs pa'i bu yin par gyur te 'gyur ba , perf. gyur properly ‘as he has come to be’.bu khyer ro// ‘There being certain two women quarrelling about one boy, the king (being) wise of understanding having examined (the case) thus ordered: You two, having seized from each (side) a hand of the boy, pull, and who gets him, (she) may carry him off.—When he had so spoken, she who was not the boy's mother, because she had no compassion for the boy, not fearing (she might) hurt (him), pulled with what force she had. She who (in truth) was the boy's mother, because she had compassion with the boy, fearing (she might) hurt (him), though she was able by force, did not pull hard. The king said to her who had pulled hard: “Because this, not being your son, is the other woman's son, say (it) outright”. When he had so spoken, as he had turned out to be the son of the gentle puller, (she) carried off the boy’.
